Title:
Timely evolution of ectomycorrhizal symbiosis spurred
adaptive radiation of fungi
Abstract:
Acquisition of mutualistic hosts potentially provides
symbionts with ecological opportunities driving evolutionary
diversification. However, it remains unclear whether origination of
mycorrhizal symbiosis could promote adaptive diversification of fungi.
Based on the phylogenic tree inferred from the nucleotide sequences of
87 single-copy genes, we reconstructed the origins of ectomycorrhizal
(ECM) symbiosis in a species-rich basidiomycetous order, Boletales. The
high-resolution phylogeny of Boletales indicated at least four
independent, asynchronous origins of ECM symbiosis. Among the four
origins, only the third earliest event, occurring in the clade of
Boletaceae, was suggested to result in a large-scale adaptive radiation
event, which was possibly fueled by the timely evolution of angiosperm
hosts (ECM rosids) and subsequent expansion to broad geographic ranges
with the novel host lineages. These results suggest that true pioneers
are not always successful and that high diversification potentials can
be made available for “timely innovators”, which initiated mutualistic
symbiosis with contemporaneously-evolving hosts that offered large niche
spaces.
